bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 30, 1876

div1.p: Reed studies Emilie Lawrence's French grammar. He assures her of his devotion. He visits Central Park, New York City.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 30, 1876
div1.p:
Last
Monday evening, I anxiously
awaited the arrival of your
letter & my heart beat right
merrily, as the declining day
wore away. Alas! the mes-
senger came, but no letter
for me: so I heaved a sigh,
declared the regular mail
communications were impos-
sible, & hence not to be expec-
ted, and went to my din-
ner- Returning, I took up my
(your) French grammar, feeling
that, to hold in my hands a
volume whose leaves had been
so often turned by your
precious little fingers, would
bring me as near to you as
possible. And sure enough,
it was quite a satisfac-
tion to observe, here & there,
scattered throughout the book,
“foot-prints” of my little Emilie-
or if not exactly “foot-prints,”
hand-prints, which, by the way,
you were so cruel as to erase
before consigning it to my care.
In spite of the fact that they
were all pretty well erased,
I had the pleasure of puz-
zling my brain in the attempt
to dechipher them. I found
two or three short sentences
that were not erased at all,
& they were all composed of
the same number of words,
& the same words. Although
I agreed with the sentiment
expressed by those words, I
don't know that I can tell
you, just yet, what they were.
Of course, you don't remember
them, & haven't the remotest
curiosity to be informed
whether I shall relent & tell
you or not, this much I will
confide to you- that it was, &
is, the greatest pleasure to
be permitted to study a for-
eign tongue out of the very
identical “tome” that has so often
met the gaze of my little love's
eyes, & perhaps brought a frown
to my little darling's brow! In-
deed, I feel & know that the very
same portions of the work that
puzzled you, must necessa-
rily give me most trouble.
It couldn't be otherwise, my
sweet Em, so much alike
are we in mind - albeit,
to tease me, you occasionly
deny that there is any sim-
ilarity; but I understand that
you don't mean it, or else
I should be very much teased.
Really, I believe I had almost
forgotten to tell you what
I started out to relate, &
that was concerning your
last letter- Well, as I said, I
studied my lesson in French,
& then went up stairs to
my room to read an hour
or two before retiring.
Sometime after 9 o'clock, a voice
summoned me from below,
to the effect that there was a
letter down stairs for me,
and sure enough, on descen-
ding, I found your precious
letter on a remote corner
of the table, just where it
had been quietly reposing
since 5 o'clock! The orderly,
it seems, had, contrary to his
usual custom, divided the letters
& papers in to two packages &
scattered them around gen-
erally- I cannot tell you,
my love, how sweet that
letter was to my longing eyes, & how I pressed
it to my heart, when I had again reached
my room! God bless you, for the sweet
assurances that it contained! If aught
my previous letter contained has contrib-
uted to your happiness, know, my darling,
that the knowledge of the very fact that
I have caused your heart to beat more
happily, this has yielded me, as nothing
else on earth can give, comfort & joy
such as I have never known!

Yesterday, for the first time within 4 weeks, I
visited New York City, & spent the greater part
of the day in Central Park, feasting on the
loneliness & grandeur of Nature as well as
the wonders of Art. My trip did me much
good, as it was the first day's relaxation I
had taken since my return from M'boro- Strolling
down Broadway, late in the afternoon, I dropped into
Carleton's Publishing House, and as a result of what I
saw, I send you by, to-day's, mail a little vol. called “Flor-
al Decoration of Dwelling Houses”-which I trust may be of interest- The
sentences in the grammar were, “I love you, Emilie”- and I do, with all my heart-
